title: 'Act of forgery': FIFA accuses Malaysia of faking foreign players' eligibility | ABC News
description: Global football's governing body FIFA has found Malaysia "cheated" by forging documentation to improperly naturalise foreign players from South America and Europe. While the international players' union says the seven players are "victims", FIFA has imposed a 12-month suspension on them. FIFA has also lodged criminal complaints in five countries and launched its own investigation into the Football Association of Malaysia. ABC journalist Max Walden spoke to the World's Girish Sawlani about the impact the scandal has had on Malaysian football. title: Japan locals on alert for more earthquakes after overnight shock | The World | ABC NEWS
description: More than 30 people have been injured after a magnitude 7.5 earthquake in Japan's north-east. Rebecca Johnston reports 90,000 people had to evacuate buildings, and authorities are now warning residents to be on alert for more quakes in the coming week. title: Australia's teen social media ban is here — what happens now? | ABC NEWS
description: Australia's world-first social media ban for teens has come into effect, but what will that actually look like? As Ruby Cornish explains, it's now up to platforms captured by the ban to integrate age verification processes, which could look different across the board. title: Interest rates likely to be on hold or hiked in the next 12 months, says AMP | The Business
description: As expected, the Reserve Bank has kept the cash rate on hold until February. But the RBA Governor says the board's next move could be a rate rise if inflation doesn't begin to ease back towards the target band.  Michele Bullock says there's a lot of uncertainty about how that will play out, but more rate cuts are not on the horizon. AMP deputy chief economist Diana Mousina joined The Business to explain where she thinks rates will head next year.  She says the RBA governor's speech could be described as "hawkish" and "that's likely to mean that interest rates are either going to be on hold or increased in the next 12 month. Diana Mousina says in AMP's view, the risks to the economy are to the downside in 2026. "That hangs on this expectation that the labour market is likely to weaken a bit further, which then has implications for inflation," she said.  #ABCBusiness Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE   ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: People on the streets of London react to Australia's world-first social media ban | ABC NEWS
description: European nations are considering following Australia’s lead in banning under-16s from social media, after the European parliament passed a resolution encouraging EU governments to make the move.  France is weighing stricter legislation on social media use for children.  ABC Europe correspondent Elias Clure spoke to some UK residents, who had mixed feelings about the ban. title: Rare dinosaur skeleton goes to auction prompting criticism from paleontologists | ABCS NEWS
description: A rare dinosaur fossil exhibit is going under the hammer in London with a price guide of $6 million to $10 million. The skeleton, dubbed ‘Spike’,  is part of caenagnathid family of dinosaurs which roamed the earth 68 million years ago.  Christie’s auction house’s James Hyslop says interest in the specimen from international collectors is huge.  Critics of fossil auctions and sales such have raised concerns about private collections blocking access for to exhibits for dinosaur researchers such as the Natural History Museum’s Susannah Maidment. title: Which houses will survive this bushfire season? | ABC News Daily podcast
description: In the first week of summer, dozens of homes have been destroyed in bushfires; at Dolphin Sands in Tasmania, on the New South Wales Central Coast, and at Bulahdelah, north of Newcastle where a firefighter also died.     A local builder at Koolewong in New South Wales noted that a recently constructed home, built to modern fire safety standards, was left standing while others around it burned to the ground.    Today, the ABC’s Central Coast reporter Sarah Forster on the homes that were lost in Saturday’s fire and an expert on building houses in high bushfire risk areas.   Featured:    Sarah Forster, ABC Central Coast reporter    Colin Wood, member of the Standards Australia committee for the construction of buildings in bushfire-prone areas

title: Major delays and serial concert pest Johnson Wen kicked out of Lady Gaga Brisbane concert | ABC NEWS
description: Lady Gaga fans were left stranded for hours trying to get into Brisbane’s Suncorp Stadium, with some missing the start of the show altogether. In a statement, a spokesperson for Suncorp Stadium said the gates opened 50 minutes later than they should have due to "technical issues" identified during a sound check. Meanwhile serial concert pest Johnson Wen who made headlines by grabbing Ariana Grande in Singapore was kicked out of the stadium. title: Zelenskyy prepared to hold Ukrainian election within 3 months | ABC NEWS
description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has pledged to hold an election within three months if the US and Kyiv’s other allies can provide security assurances. The Ukrainian leader and some European counterparts are set to table a revised peace proposal after Washington proposed a 28-point peace plan, which was criticised for being too favourable to Russia. US President Donald Trump suggested in an interview with Politico that the Zelenskyy administration was prolonging the Ukraine war to cling to power. title: NSW RFS preparing for above average fire season | ABC NEWS
description: Parts of NSW are forecast to receive between 20mm-50mm of rain on Thursday and Friday, easing concerns about immediate fire danger.     However, a lack of rain in the spring means there is less soil moisture and an increased fuel load, so the RFS is warning of an average to above-average fire season. title: Australia has officially banned social media for under-16s | ABC NEWS
description: Australia's ambitious, world-first social media ban for children under 16 officially starts today.  So far, the law applies to only ten of the bajillion or so websites in the world you might describe as social media. The platforms in question are:  ■ Facebook ■ Instagram ■ TikTok ■ Snapchat ■ X (formerly Twitter) ■ YouTube ■ Reddit ■ Twitch ■ Kick ■ Threads  Already, there are signs plenty of teens planning to move to other platforms that aren't covered by the new rules, but there's no guarantee those sites will be left out of the ban forever.  #ABCNews #SocialMediaBan  Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: Taronga Zoo to transform farmland in NSW for native animals | ABC NEWS
description: More than 3,000 hectares of land in northern NSW is set to be transformed into a safe haven for endangered native species including koalas, spotted quolls and platypuses. Andrew Elphinstone from the Taronga Conservation Society says protecting what’s left is not enough and the aim of the program is to restore the habitat for the animals.
